entry.title: Cryptic encoding error message when writing a review
entry.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? *Firstly this is difficult for me to give you steps to reproduce because it was a private comment to a student which causing the problem so I can't paste in the text. But:) 1. I visited a student application 2, I wrote a comment in the tinymce field comment field. The text contained new lines and a URL and only UK English. 3. I was presented with the following cryptic error message: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xa0' in position 5: ordinal not in range(128) In order to try and work around the issue: 1. I attempted to resolve the error by copying the text in so a Mac OSX textedit, converting to plain text and pasting in again. But I still could not post my comment. 2. I removed the link (thinking it may somehow have introduced some character when I copied it) 3. Finally I disabled javascript and pasted the text into the text field and could save successfully. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? I should be able to post the comment whether I was using tinymce or not. On what URL are you testing: http://www.google-melange.com/gsoc/dashboard/google/gsoc2012 What version was the URL you tested at running : VERSION 2-0-20120428 Which browser were you using? Google Chrome on Mac OS X Lion When did you encounter the problem? When trying to write a feedback comment for a student. Please provide any additional information below.
entry.issues:label: Type-Defect
Priority-Critical

entry.title: Program host should be able to review student profiles while program is in progress
entry.content:
We require students to submit certain forms and documents, and we review those, but we currently store outside of Melange the fact of our having reviewed and approved (or bounced) those documents.
(1) Student profiles should have a notion of "approved by program host",
and
(2) Program hosts should be able to query for unapproved student profiles, review those profiles, and mark them as approved or still unapproved.

entry.title: Having issues getting mentors signed up for GCI
entry.content: *Please note that issues filed that do not follow this template will be marked as Invalid* What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Ask a potential mentor to apply and fill out their profile at: http://www.google-melange.com/gci/profile/mentor/google/gci2012 2. They do and it shows up in the org admin box as pending but when clicking on it we get an error saying that the request id 2001 (or 17001) doesn't exist. 3. On their end they get an invite but clicking on that they get error invite request 3001 doesn't exist. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? A mentor is added to the org's mentor pool. On what URL are you testing (e.g. http://www.google- melange.com/gsoc/dashboard/google/gsoc2011)? http://www.google-melange.com/gci/profile/mentor/google/gci2012 What version was the URL you tested at running (e.g. version 2-0-20111123-p2, see bottom of page)? Version 2-0-20121112 Which browser were you using? Firefox 16.0.2 When did you encounter the problem? 12:10 PM PST 2012/11/12 Please provide any additional information below. This is similar to (but not exactly) the issue we ran into in 2011 trying to get new mentors signed in, it shouldn't be this difficult: http://code.google.com/p/soc/issues/detail?id=1337

entry.title: GCI Student registration form textual changes (umbrella issue)
entry.content:
In the student profile registration form: 1. Change the field name "Username" to "URL ID"
2. Text indicating that shipping info need not be filled if residence address is same as shipping address should move to the shipping info group heading.
3. Display the link to student forms upload page after successfully creating the student profile.
4. Student ID form field label should be called "Enrollment Form".
4. Student upload forms help text for student id form should say "scan of your Student ID, School transcript or letter from school. For examples click here (at the bottom of the page)".
5. When both the forms are uploaded we should show a message saying students can now claim tasks.

entry.title: Projects accepted but withdrawn by student still count against slot total

On what URL are you testing (e.g. http://socghop.appspot.com)? http://www.google-melange.com What version was the URL you tested at running (e.g. 0.5.1)? Version 2-0-20110420 Which browser were you using? Firefox 4 When did you encounter the problem? 2011/04/21 Please provide any additional information below. Fixed by going to the withdrawn project (via a URL in a notification email for it, since it was no longer linked in the proposal list) and manually marking it as not accepted.

entry.title: Don't show todo entries before they can be done
entry.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. hang out on #gsoc 2. listen to many students asking about how they can send in proof of enrollment and tax forms, which they are asking about because melange lists them as a todo item 3. get bored of telling them to wait for carols to send out an email about how to do this 4. file bug against melange What is the expected output? entry.title: Documents should offer templating features
entry.content:
Advanced Document authors should be able to use a (tightly-controlled) subset of Django template context in their Documents.
Based on the User Role in which a Document is created, certain context variables and other template expansion features should be made available to Document authors. For example, it would be useful to a Program Administrator (site Host) to be able to refer to {{ program_name }} in a Document and have that be expanded from the Program settings entity.
Exposed template variables would need to be well-documented and then prohibited from being changed once they were in widespread use.
entry.issues:label: Type-Enhancement
Priority-High
Component-UI
Component-Logic
Effort-Modest
Milestone-1

entry.title: Logos should be required to look good at 64x64
entry.content: Currently (https://code.google.com/p/soc/source/browse/app/soc/models/organization.py) we say "Please ensure that the image you provide is smaller than 65px65px.". This leaves wiggle-room enough for good people at GNOME to give us a 24x24 image, which we can then either scale up to look blurry or leave tiny next to all the other full-size logos. We should simply require that logos are 64x64 (or are such that they look good when rendered at 64x64) and be done with it.

entry.content: We need to introduce the concept of 'optional' columns, that are not retrieved until the user requests them. entry.title: Host needs a special access checker
entry.content:
Host needs an access checker that inherits from the regular one but overrides a few methods. These methods currently have something like:
try: self.isHost() # allow host return except AccessViolation: pass
It would be better if we remove that check from those methods and instead override to do nothing in the Host checker.

entry.content: *Please note that issues filed that do not follow this template will be marked as Invalid* What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Select 'My Oprganizations', choose one, then 'Edit' 2. Scroll to the middle of the page 3. Find the Amazing and Desired entry fields This is REALLY sub-optimal. Several org admins have indicated that they are having trouble finding these. These should be moved to the Org Dashboard. Ideally the form would be on that page, front and center, no click-through required. Along these same lines, if you're going to call it a Dashboard, it would be good to collect other statistics here too: number of apps received/ignored/accepted, number of mentors, etc. But really, move the things needed for organization administrators to do their jobs front and center, ideally with enough descriptive text to lmit the number of user questions. Regards, - Brian

entry.title: Usability suggestions
entry.content:
A user writes (https://groups.google.com/group/melange-soc-dev/browse_thread/thread/14af7d9cf56cf625):
Melange seems to be very optimized for a large number of items. This makes sense for you super-admin guys with hundreds of students/projects/mentors listed. But for the majority of users (org admins, mentors and students), it[']s a major usability issue.
Best example: The page for my (only) organization is tucked away in a "My organizations" area, and the link to it fills about 2% of the available screen space in a 10px font table row.
Also, actions should be in context: I would expect to invite mentors on the "Members of my organizations" page (and choose the organization I'm inviting to).
All good, slowly finding my way around :) Makes sense to start with a unified super-admin and user interface in terms of reduced maintenance effort, and built out from there.
entry.issues:label: Usability
Priority-Low

entry.title: Merge proposals, projects and accepted organization admin pages
entry.content: The admin dashboard has links to proposals, projects and accepted organizations under "Manage organizations" heading. They all more or less duplicate the data (and a lot of code), all for linking each row in the list to a different place. What we should alternatively do is merge those 3 lists and make the individual columns link to the respective pages, i.e. num of proposals column can link to the list of all the proposals for the organization, num of projects column can link to the list of projects page and the row itself can link to the organization home page.

entry.title: Re-design the dashboard for users having multiple dashboards
entry.content:
Currently Melange shows TWO dashboards for an org admin: "org admin dashboard" (currently, in proposal/selection period, shows two useless links) and the "my dashboard" which isn't a dashboard at all (in the sense of providing dials, indicators, etc: useful data) but just a list of links.
Proposal (1): move all the links from both 'dashboards' into the left-hand navigation pane. Only show links to functionality that currently actually has capability for the current logged in user and within the current GSOC period.
Proposal (2): replace the 'home' page with something that shows useful stuff specific to the user in question. Suggested information would be:
* for a student: list of orgs (during proposal period) then the status of their proposals (during evaluation period) then any requests/todos/feedback (during the coding period)
* for a mentor: (during proposal period) list of all proposals, perhaps wtih ability to 'star' the interesting ones? (during evaluation period) list of starred proposals, list of projects volunteers to mentor, link to overall ranked proposals (during coding period): list of projects being mentored
* for a org admin: as for mentor, plus list of proposals 'active' in current period at top.
I think this would greatly help usability of the current site.
entry.issues:label: Priority-Low

entry.title: For a GSoC proposal, "Publicly Visible" option can be split up as "Visible to other students" and "Visible to all"
entry.content: What new or enhanced feature are you proposing? I wish that a feature "Visible only to students" be added for all the GSoC proposals made by students. This should be along with the existing option "Publicly Visible". The new option would allow only users with an account to view the proposal, while not allowing anyone else to view it. What goal would this enhancement help you achieve? Proposals usually include personal information that a student would like to share with one's organisation, so that the student can be contacted. However this means that one must keep the proposal private, to avoid misuse of information or to avoid being spammed. By adding the above feature students would be able to view proposals made by others, while web crawlers wouldn't be able to index them. This option would be quite easy to implement.
entry.issues:label: Priority-Optional

entry.title: Keep a "chocolate for Carol" counter in org admin dashboard
entry.content: What new or enhanced feature are you proposing? Often, orgs ask Carol to do stuff without offering chocolate in return. Because especially for bigger orgs, many mentors can bother Carol without the org admins being involved, the chocolate Carol deserves should be tracked in a central place. What goal would this enhancement help you achieve? A chocolate counter on the org admin's dashboard would help the org admin to keep track on how much chocolate the mentor summit delegates need to bring along. This would allow to coordinate getting both an adequately sized and diverse selection of chocolate to the mentor summit.

entry.content:
So I can't pay a student who hasn't submitted his/her tax forms and proof of enrollment forms more than $500.
So I would like a feature where even if the student has passed the midterm evaluation, he/she is flagged as having not submitted his/her forms so I know at a glance not to pay him/her any more money.
As it stands now I have to manually compare between the list of students who haven't submitted their forms and the list of students who have passed the midterm evaluation and manually delete them from the list of students to receive payments from citibank.

entry.title: If a an accepted project is listed as failed or undecided I can't see the mentor
entry.content:
If a student's project gets listed as failed or undecided at the midterm or final evaluation it is removed from the accepted projects page and from the listed projects on the organization's homepage. This is the expected behavior.
However, the way that I currently find out who the mentor is for a project is by navigating from the organization's homepage. So if a student is in the "undecided" state I have no place where I can find out who that project's mentor is when the project is in that state. Please make a page where I can see ALL accepted projects (failed or otherwise) and the organization, but most importantly, mentor's name. I need to be able to contact both the appropriate mentor and the org admins when an evaluation hasn't been submitted of a student.
